notes: Updated for Nullblock as the canonical bottom layer and added Artificer’s Workbench as an in-game station.

loreLines: The world’s final layer—stone that rejects change.
Nullrock is not a material so much as a rule: 'no further'.
Old builders wrote Corestone in their ledgers. The Covenant speaks the truer name: Nullblock.
A quiet place where the ordinary becomes deliberate.
The Ancients wrote: measure twice, open once.
Embercoal—fuel for early work and safer heat.
Continuists preferred it to open flame near thin places.
Anchor-iron—heavy, honest, and willing to hold a shape.
Used in frames and clamps when the Veil pushes back.
Sunmetal—too soft for walls, perfect for conductors.
It carries alignment cleanly when tuned with care.
Facetstone—hard enough to cut a rule, not just a rock.
Ancient keystones were etched with diamond dust.
A common box, until it keeps something you shouldn’t forget.
Many fragments survive because someone stored them and walked away.
A bench built for rulework: carving, tuning, and sealing the smallest parts that hold the biggest doors.
Where a Crafting Table joins materials, the Workbench joins intentions—Frame, Conduit, Limiter, all in one place.
Continuist benches were etched to refuse haste: if the pattern is wrong, the tools simply do not bite.
